prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP9 - HNC(4-3), HCO+(4-3), HCN(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SDP9 (z=1.577) 2 basebands for spectral lines HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), HNC(4-3) 2 basebands for continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The three spectral lines in this science goal at the source redshift are at the following frequencies: HCN(4-3) 137.6 GHz HCO+(4-3) 138.4 GHz HCN(4-3) 140.7 GHz
We need two separate basebands to detect them. Two further basebands will be used for continuum. We request an intermediate spectral resolution for the spectral line dedicated basebands to have a better control of the width for the brightest spectral lines. They might be further smoothed to improve sensitivity at the data reduction stage.

The requested resolution is comparable with that achieved with HST, and better than those obtained with SMA and Chandra for the same target. Attempts for source reconstructions on the basis of the available low resolution images end in displacements of the peak of the emission. Simulations of the requested ALMA observations (Fig.2 in the Science case) indicate that comparison of the different continuum spectral lines emission to the requested resolution will be enough to better locate the various emitting components and reconstruct their interaction to a <1 kpc scale (corresponding to 0.4'' at the source redshift).

We aim at determining the properties of the emitting regions surrounding the black hole hosted in the lensed galaxy SDP9, by detecting dense gas spectral lines tracers HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), HNC(4-3).
An ALMA Band 3 Cycle 2 observation is available for SDP9 (Proj.ID:2012.1.00915.S PI: Lupu), with a detection of the (3-2) transitions of HCN, HCO+ and HCN to a 3'' resolution. Spectral lines show about 500km/s FWHM. By stacking ALMA spectra of lensed galaxies, Spilker et al. (2013) shows that in this kind of objects the (4-3) transition of the lines is about a factor 2.5 stronger than the (3-2) transition. From the SMA and HST images we know that the emission comes from a region in he image plane corresponding to about one third of the Einstein ring of 0.71'' radius and 0.2'' thickness. Hence we estimated the HCN(4-3) peak flux density by rescaling the measured HCN(3-2) peak flux density to the requested 0.4'' resolution and multiplying by the 2.5 factor. The requested sensitivity should allow the 5 sigma detection for HCN(4-3) and guarantee a higher significance detection for HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3). However, we stress that the detection of HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) lines will be enough to reach most of the scientific goals of our project: the additional detection of HNC(4-3) will strengthen some conclusion and improve the characterization of our targets in the source plane.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP9 - CO(3-2), CN(3-2), CS(7-6)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SDP9 (z=1.577) 1 baseband for spectral lines CO(3-2), CN(3-2) and CS(7-6) 3 basebands for continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The three spectral lines in this science goal at the source redshift are at the following frequencies: CO(3-2) 134.2 GHz CN(3-2) 131.9 GHz CS(7-6) 133.1 GHz
They all fall within the same 1.875 GHz wide basebands. Three further basebands will be used for continuum. We request an intermediate spectral resolution to investigate the dynamics of the CO(3-2) line. They might be further smoothed to improve sensitivity at the data reduction stage.

The requested resolution is comparable with that achieved with HST, and better than those obtained with SMA and Chandra for the same target. Attempts for source reconstructions on the basis of the available low resolution images end in displacements of the peak of the emission. Simulations of the requested ALMA observations (Fig.2 in the Science case) indicate that comparison of the different continuum spectral lines emission to the requested resolution will be enough to better locate the various emitting components and reconstruct their interaction to a <1 kpc scale (corresponding to 0.4'' at the source redshift).

We aim at determining the properties of the low-density regions and dynamics and star formation in the lensed galaxy SDP9 by measuring to high spectral resolution the CO(3-2) line and, as a byproduct, detecting the CN(3-2) and CS(7-6) lines.
A PdBI measure of the CO(3-2) line is available for SDP9 to a 3'' resolution (Omont et al. 2013). Integrated flux densities for this and other transitions are given in Table 1. From the SMA and HST images we know that the emission comes from a region in he image plane corresponding to about one third of the Einstein ring of 0.71'' radius and 0.2'' thickness. Hence we estimated the CO(3-2) peak flux density by rescaling the measured flux density to the requested 0.4'' resolution and to the requested spectral resolution to estimate sensitivity.
The requested sensitivity will be enough to detect the spectral line over at least 10 channels. In the same time, over a lower spectral resolution we have the chance to detect the CN(3-2) and the CS(7-6) spectral lines (respectively a factor 8 and 16 fainter than CO(3-2) according to Spilker et al. (2014)).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP11 - HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), HNC(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SDP11 - z=1.786 2 basebands for spectral lines HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), HNC(4-3) 2 basebands for continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The three spectral lines in this science goal at the source redshift are at the following frequencies: HCN(4-3) 127.2 GHz HCO+(4-3) 128.0 GHz HCN(4-3) 130.2 GHz We need two separate basebands to detect them. Two further basebands will be used for continuum. We request an intermediate spectral resolution for the spectral line dedicated basebands to have a better control of the width for the brightest spectral lines. They might be further smoothed to improve sensitivity at the data reduction stage.

The requested resolution is comparable to that achieved with HST, and better than those obtained with SMA and Chandra for the same target. Attempts for source reconstructions on the basis of the available low resolution images end in displacements of the peak of the emission. Simulations of the requested ALMA observations (Fig.2 in the Science case) indicate that comparison of the different continuum spectral lines emission to the requested resolution will be enough to better locate the various emitting components and reconstruct their interaction to a <1 kpc scale (corresponding to 0.4'' at the source redshift).

We aim at determining the properties of the emitting regions surrounding the black hole hosted in the lensed galaxy SDP11, by detecting dense gas spectral lines tracers HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3), HNC(4-3).
An ALMA Band 3 Cycle 2 observation is available for SDP11 (Proj.ID:2012.1.00915.S PI: Lupu), with a detection of the (3-2) transitions of HCN, HCO+ and HCN to a 3'' resolution. Spectral lines show about 500km/s FWHM. By stacking ALMA spectra of lensed galaxies, Spilker et al. (2013) shows that in this kind of objects the (4-3) transition of the lines is about a factor 2.5 stronger than the (3-2) transition. From the SMA and HST images we know that the emission comes from a region in he image plane corresponding to about one third of the Einstein ring of 0.84'' radius and 0.2'' thickness. Hence we estimated the HCN(4-3) peak flux density by rescaling the measured HCN(3-2) peak flux density to the requested 0.4'' resolution and multiplying by the 2.5 factor. The requested sensitivity should allow the 5 sigma detection for HCN(4-3) and guarantee a higher significance detection for HNC(4-3) and HCO+(4-3). However, we stress that the detection of HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) lines will be enough to reach most of the scientific goals of our project: the additional detection of HNC(4-3) will strengthen some conclusion and improve the characterization of our targets in the source plane. Although one transition is enough to trace the high density gas in the source place, another transition, the (5-4), of HCN, HCO+ and HNC will be detected as part of the last science goal together with the CO(4-3) line. This is not redundant as the two transitions, once combined with the already available measuremnts of HCN(3-2), HCO+(3-2) and HNC(3-2) will allow us to constrain the temperature, density and mass of the dense gas through multi-line fitting.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDP11 - CO(4-3), HCN(5-4), HCO+(5-4), HNC(5-4), CN(4-3)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: SDP11 - (z=1.786) 1 baseband for spectral lines CN(4-3), CO(4-3) 1 baseband for spectral lines HCN(5-4), HCO+(5-4), HNC(5-4), 2 basebands for continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The three spectral lines in this science goal at the source redshift are at the following frequencies: HCN(5-4) 159.0 GHz HCO+(5-4) 160.1 GHz HNC(5-4) 162.1 GHz CO(5-4) 162.8 The fall within two 1.875 GHz wide basebands. Two further basebands will be used for continuum. We request an intermediate spectral resolution to investigate the dynamics of the CO(3-2) line. They might be further smoothed to improve sensitivity at the data reduction stage.

The requested resolution is comparable with that achieved with HST, and better than those obtained with SMA and Chandra for the same target. Attempts for source reconstructions on the basis of the available low resolution images end in displacements of the peak of the emission. Simulations of the requested ALMA observations (Fig.2 in the Science case) indicate that comparison of the different continuum spectral lines emission to the requested resolution will be enough to better locate the various emitting components and reconstruct their interaction to a <1 kpc scale (corresponding to 0.4'' at the source redshift).

We aim at determining the properties of the low-density regions and dynamics and star formation in the lensed galaxy SDP11 by measuring to high spectral resolution the CO(4-3) line and, as a byproduct, detecting the HCN(5-4), HCO+(5-4), HNC(5-4) and CN(4-3) lines.
By extrapolating existing measurements of higher CO transitions we estimate the CO(3-2) line emission. From the SMA and HST images we know that the emission comes from a region in he image plane corresponding to about one third of the Einstein ring of 0.71'' radius and 0.2'' thickness. Hence we estimated the CO(3-2) peak flux density by rescaling the measured flux density to the requested 0.4'' resolution and to the requested spectral resolution to estimate sensitivity.
The requested sensitivity will be enough to detect the spectral line over at least 10 channels. In the same time, over a lower spectral resolution we have the chance to detect the HCN(5-4), HCO+(5-4) and the CN(4-3) spectral lines (estimated to be a factor 4 fainter). A weak detection of HNC(5-4) is also possible in the same spectral setup. We stress that the detection of the CO line is the main taget of the current SG, but the detection of at least one transition for each of HCN, HCO+ and HNC is crucial for the whole project. The combination of multi-line transitions of HCN, HCO+ and HNC will allow us a precise determination of density, temperature and mass for the dense gas component in the surroundings of the hosted AGN.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose Band 4 ~0.4" spatial resolution observations of both low density and high density gas tracers (CO, HCN, HCO+ and HNC) in two dusty starforming galaxies at redshifts z=1.577 and z=1.786 that we recently confirmed, by means of Chandra X-ray observations, to host and obscured AGN. Both galaxies are gravitationally lensed thus making the detection of such lines possible in few hours integration time on source. We will use these observations to build a picture of the background galaxy structure and properties by (i) tracing the AGN, the star formation and the dense molecular gas fuel on ~ 1kpc spatial scales in the source plane; (ii) characterizing the effect of the starburst and AGN on the surrounding environment by measuring the density, temperature and mass of the dense gas; (iii) determining the morphology, the dynamics and the mass of the molecular gas reservoir.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00915.S, "Measurements of high density gas tracers in lensed submillimeter galaxies", PI: R. Lupu
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
